cmCourseInfo.description: Ranging widely chronologically and geographically, this course explores the phenomenon of violence in history. It examines the role and meanings of violence in particular societies (such as ancient Greece and samurai Japan), the ideological foundations and use of violence in the clash of cultures (as in slavery, holy wars, colonization, and genocide), and the effects and memorialization of violence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Histories of Violence
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: None
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS100Y1, HIS102Y1, HIS103Y1, HIS106Y1, HIS107Y1, HIS108Y1, HIS109Y1, HIS110Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In fall term:  lectures asynchronous; tutorials synchronous and online.  

In winter term:  if public health conditions permit, in-person lectures, with recorded lectures posted on-line and accessible asynchronously (otherwise, lectures as in fall term); tutorials synchrounous & online

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

courses.name: Statecraft and Strategy: An Introduction to the History of International Relations

cmCourseInfo.description: An analysis of the development of the international system, from 1648 to 1945, which highlights the role of war as an instrument of national policy, as a determinant of the system of states and as a threat to international society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Statecraft and Strategy: An Introduction to the History of International Relations
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS100Y1, HIS101Y1, HIS102Y1, HIS106Y1, HIS107Y1, HIS108Y1, HIS109Y1, HIS110Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded and posted online for asynchronous viewing. 

Tutorials will be online-only and will run synchronously during regular timetable slots. 

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers an introduction to history as a discipline - to the history of the discipline itself, to the questions, categories, and methodologies that constitute it, and how they have evolved in varied times and places, and to the methodologies students need to acquire to engage in historical inquiry and writing. The course will be part methodological workshop, part epistemological reflection.
cmCourseInfo.title: What is History?
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS100Y1, HIS101Y1, HIS102Y1, HIS103Y1, HIS106Y1, HIS107Y1, HIS109Y1, HIS110Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

In fall term: lectures asynchronous; tutorials synchronous and online  

In winter term: if public health conditions permit, in-person lectures, with recorded lectures posted on-line and accessible asynchronously (otherwise, lectures as in fall term); tutorials synchronous & online

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

courses.name: Connected Histories from Dakar to Jakarta

cmCourseInfo.description: In 1325, the twenty-year old Moroccan, Ibn Battuta, began an unprecedented series of journeys by land and sea that stretched between the contemporary capitals of Senegal and Indonesia. His routes wove together large parts of Africa, Central & South Asia, and East & Southeast Asia. For more than a thousand years before Battuta began his journey, other travelers had transported ideas, products, and scripts across each of these routes, connecting the histories of the peoples living throughout this vast landmass. Human migration, economic trade, and religious conversion had linked the lands and the seas, making possible for Ibn Battuta to traverse these territories, and to visit the religious homelands of Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam and their expanse across the Africa and Asia. Nearly a thousand years after Ibn Battuta’s travels, human migration, economic trade, and religious conversion continue to affect and connect the cultures, ecology, and economies of these communities. This course investigates how the creation, disruption, and maintenance of the economic, linguistic, and religious communities in the millennium before and after Ibn Battuta’s travels affected the lives and livelihoods of peoples of Africa and Asia, where 80% of the world’s population resided, then and today.
cmCourseInfo.title: Connected Histories from Dakar to Jakarta
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS100Y1, HIS101Y1, HIS102Y1, HIS103Y1, HIS106Y1, HIS107Y1, HIS108Y1, HIS109Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

HyFlex lectures recorded permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance.  Tutorials Online synchronous.  Some in-person lecture opportunities should public health guidelines permit.

cmCourseInfo.description: A first-year seminar on the history of queerness, in all its complexity and diversity, in the no less complex and diverse settings of East, South, and Southeast Asia. Our journey will encompass empires and Indigenous peoples, rulers and rebels, and range from early recorded history down to the twentieth century. Focus will be placed on primary sources and introducing students to the evolving definitions of "queerness" itself. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: A History of Queer Asia

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Hy-Flex:  Live-stream recorded, Synchronous discussion with some in-person opportunities should public health guidelines permit.

courses.name: Power, Resistance, and the Graphic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will look broadly at the question of power and resistance in the Americas (Canada, the United States, and Latin America) through the prism of graphic novels. Each week we will read a graphic novel related to important historical moments or events, drawing on scholarly articles to help us contextualize the novel. We will discuss the medium of graphic novels, their history and place in the broader culture, as well as how they might help or hinder our ability to study and disseminate information about the past. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Power, Resistance, and the Graphic Novel

cmCourseInfo.description: Histories of wine or beer or vodka often focus either on the production of these alcoholic beverages and their role in national economies, or the ways that drinking is part of celebrations. But drunkenness enters the historical record in other ways, too--not just as a social lubricant but as a social ill, one associated with intimate violence or violence to the self and with mass protest. From worries about the Gin Craze to the rise of temperance movements and eventually the passing of Prohibition, from tax policies to policing, this class will consider the many ways that drunkenness has been accepted, denounced, and legislated about in societies around the world. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Drunk History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

LEC9101 will be online synchronous lectures.

cmCourseInfo.description: In this seminar we will explore the complex roles of religion in cases of extreme violence. Working chronologically backward from the 1990s (Rwanda, former Yugoslavia), we will consider cases from a number of locations and decades in the 20th Century (Cambodia in the 1970s, the Holocaust in the 1940s, Armenians in the 1910s, Southwest Africa in the 1900s). Rather than limiting ourselves to the recent past, we will also explore cases from the 19th century (imperialism) and earlier as well as ongoing situations that connect past and present (aboriginal people in the Americas). Students will be expected to do the assigned reading (from personal accounts, primary sources, and scholarly articles), participate actively in discussions, prepare a series of short responses, make and oral presentation individually or with a group, and produce a final paper based on original research. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Religion and Violence

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Women and Gender in Latin American History

sections.name: LEC9101
sections.subTitle: Women and Gender in Latin American History

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 8, 2021: Day and time change.</br>October 26, 2020: Delivery method changed

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the diverse experiences of women from a comparative perspective. Students will study how women’s strategies have shaped the major cultural, economic, political and social processes in the world and how these processes have affected women’s experiences in their particular societies. By studying women’s history from both local and global perspectives, students will engage critically with claims that women’s history is universal. The local focus of the course will rotate between Africa, Asia, Europe, and North America, depending on the expertise of the instructors.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Women's History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: None

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Both course sections will be online with synchronous lectures and tutorials.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of the Jews throughout the world over the past two thousand years.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of the Jewish People

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Hy-Flex:  Lectures are live-streamed and recorded online permitting synchronous delivery, but also asynchronous attendance. Some in-person opportunities should public health guidelines permit.  Tutorials are online synchronous.

cmCourseInfo.description: A lecture-based course designed to introduce students to key moments and concepts in the field of environmental history since c. 1400. This course will track the reciprocal influence of humans and the non-human world since the so-called "Columbian Exchange," emphasizing the ways in which the non-human world-from plants, animals, and disease organisms to water, topography, and geography- have shaped human endeavours. At the same time, students will engage with many of the ways in which human beings have shaped the world around us, from empire and colonization, to industrial capitalism, nuclear power, and modern wildlife conservation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Environmental History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: any 100-level History course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recorded lectures posted online and available asynchronously.  Weekly introductions and question periods held synchronously during scheduled lecture time.  

Tutorials held synchronously online.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

courses.name: Indigenous and Early Colonial Caribbean History

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the study of Caribbean history from first human settlement to the late 18th century. Subject matter covered includes indigenous social structures, cosmology and politics; the process of European conquest; the economics, society and political order of colonial society; the Middle Passage; the everyday lives and struggles of enslaved peoples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Indigenous and Early Colonial Caribbean History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: None

courses.name: Revolution and Emancipation in the Colonial Caribbean

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the history of the late eighteenth and nineteenth century caribbean, from the Haitian Revolution to the U.S. occupation of Cuba and Puerto Rico. Students learn about the first struggles for political independence; the struggle to abolish the slave trade; slave emancipation; indentureship and struggles to define freedom after emancipation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Revolution and Emancipation in the Colonial Caribbean

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online synchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to modern European history from Napoleon to the outbreak of World War I. Important political, economic, social, and intellectual changes in France, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Italy, and other countries are discussed: revolution of 1848, Italian and German unification, racism and imperialism, the evolution of science, art, and culture, labour protest, and the coming of war.
cmCourseInfo.title: Europe in the Nineteenth Century, 1815-1914

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures delivered sychronously; Tutorials online delivered synchronously

cmCourseInfo.description: The evolution of European politics, culture, and society from 1914: the two world wars, Fascism and Nazism, the post-1945 reconstruction and the movement towards European integration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Europe in the 20th Century

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online asynchronous.

 

Instructor will be available on Zoom Thursdays 9-11 for Q and A.

cmCourseInfo.description: The political, social, economic, and intellectual history of continental Europe. The Renaissance, the Reformation, Counter-reformation, growth of the territorial monarchies, the religious wars.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Modern Europe, 1450-1648

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 27, 2020: Delivery method changed.</br>November 27, 2020: Time changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: The political, social, economic, and intellectual history of continental Europe. Development of royal absolutism, social change and the crisis of the ancient regime, the Enlightenment, the French Revolution, the Napoleonic era.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Modern Europe, 1648-1815

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will introduce students to the history of European colonialism. It will analyze the nature of colonial rule, the impact of empire on both colonies and metropoles, and delve into questions of power, gender and culture. It considers slavery and abolition, imperial networks, colonial capital, colonial competition, colonial cultures, the twilight of colonial rule, and a variety of settings.
cmCourseInfo.title: European Colonialism, 1700- 1965

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online asynchronous with in-person and online synchronous tutorials.

courses.name: Canada: A Short History of Here

cmCourseInfo.description:
Designed for non-history students, this introductory survey fulfills the Society and Its Institutions breadth requirement. It is open to all who want to know more about Canada. Make sense of politics today and develop a deeper understanding of Canadian society and its institutions through study of the major events and demographic trends that have shaped the development of this country. Topics will include First Nations/newcomer relations (including treaties and the Truth & Reconciliation report), French/English relations (including Quebec separatism), regionalism, the North, economic history, constitutional developments, and the development of Canadian identity, including common symbols associated with Canada. No essay requirement. Instead, enhance your critical reading and thinking skills through short writing assignments and weekly discussions of tutorial readings.


*This course will not count towards History program requirements or as a prerequisite for upper level courses*
cmCourseInfo.title: Canada: A Short History of Here

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures Asynchronous, tutorials synchronous and online.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces key issues in Canadian history and foundational principles of historical analysis. It is primarily designed for potential History majors/specialists. It is not a comprehensive survey. Examples serve to deepen analysis and introduce important methods and debates, preparing students for upper year courses in Canadian history.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Issues in Canadian History

cmCourseInfo.description: The Federal Interpretation Act of Canada states that the ‘law is always speaking’. If the law is always speaking, then it must be speaking in present tense. But if it only speaks in present tense, does it have a past? How might we consider the field of law from different historical angles? This course will introduce students to different historical approaches to and uses of law. Using examples from a wide array of legal traditions (e.g. Common Law, Civil Law, Indigenous Law, Islamic Law), the course will help students gain a greater appreciation for the function, study, and development of law across different times and places.
cmCourseInfo.title: Law and History

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the economic, social, cultural, and political history of the United States from the colonial era to present times.
cmCourseInfo.title: American History Since 1607

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Most lectures delivered asynchronously with some in-person lectures and opportunities to interact with Professor pending public health guidelines.  Lectures will be recorded and posted online. Tutorials delivered synchronously online.

cmCourseInfo.description: A broad overview of the history of China from earliest times to the present. The emphasis is on how the meaning of China and the Chinese people have changed through history.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of China

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

 Synchronous lectures live-streamed permitting synchronous attendance, but also asynchronous attendance with some in-person opportunities should public health guidelines permit. Synchronous tutorials

cmCourseInfo.description: An introductory survey addressing major themes in the history of South Asia, examining South Asian political economy, social history, colonial power relations and the production of culture. Emphasis is on the period after 1750, particularly the study of colonialism, nationalism, and postcolonial citizenship and modernity.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of South Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: The evolution of Spanish and Portuguese America from pre-Columbian civilizations to the wars of independence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin America: The Colonial Period

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be offered via asynchronous online lectures and synchronous online tutorials.

TUT0301 will be taught in Spanish

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to African history and the methodology of history more broadly, this course sets out to question how historians do history, examine differences in theories of knowledge, and explore the relationship between academic and cultural representations of the past. The course also draws on anthropology and related disciplines.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Africa

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures delivered asynchronously and posted online, some delivered in-person should public health guidelines permit. Tutorials delivered online synchronously.

courses.name: Islam and Muslims in the Balkans

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the history of the Balkans from the fourteenth century until the present day with a particular focus on Islam, Muslims and Muslim culture. Topics include formation of Muslim communities, relations between Muslims and non-Muslims in the Ottoman and Habsburg empires, Sufi Islam, Muslims as minorities and majorities, and their experiences during the break-up of Yugoslavia. No prior knowledge of Balkan history or Islam is assumed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Islam and Muslims in the Balkans
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 FCE 200-level HIS course(s)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS389H1 (Islam and Muslims in the Balkans)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be online synchronous.  In addition to a computer, table, etc., students will need a microphone, so that they can ask questions or make comments on the material.

cmCourseInfo.description: Canadian international affairs in a broader context. Anglo-American as well as Canadian-American relations; the European background to questions such as the League of Nations, appeasement and rearmament, which directly affected Canada without this country being consulted.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Canadian International Relations
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: A course in Canadian history or politics

cmCourseInfo.description: The peopling of Canada by immigrant groups from the 1660s to the 1970s. Immigration and multiculturalism policies; migration and settlement; ethnic communities; relations with the host society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Immigration to Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The majority of the course will be based on recorded lectures posted online & accessible Asynchronously.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

cmCourseInfo.description: A general survey tracing the political, social, and cultural development of a distinct society in Quebec and the rise of self-conscious French-speaking communities elsewhere in Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Quebec and French Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures live-streamed and recorded (available for 1 week after live-stream) permitting both synchronous and asynchronous attendance.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of modern German history in the twentieth century. Topics include World War I and the postwar settlement, the Weimar Republic, the National Socialist dictatorship, the Holocaust, the division of Germany, the Cold War, German reunification, Germany and the European Union, nationalism, political culture, war and revolution, religious and ethnic minorities and questions of history and memory.
cmCourseInfo.title: 20th Century Germany
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS103Y1/HIS109Y1/(HIS241H1, HIS242H1)/EUR200Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given online and synchronously with recorded lectures posted online & accessible asynchronously. Students need to be able to access Quercus & BB Collaborate.  It is recommenced that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: What happens when histories of Canada begin in the West? This course examines the critical challenges that the myths and legacies of the West pose to Canadian history, from pre-contract to 1990. Themes include First Nations and colonialism, immigration, racism, economic development, regionalism, prostitution and illegal economies.
cmCourseInfo.title: The "Wild" West in Canada

courses.name: Barbarian Invasions and the Fall of the Roman Empire

cmCourseInfo.description: Covers major events and themes for the period 300-600, including decline of Greco-Roman paganism, conversion to Christianity, individual barbarian groups (Ostrogoths, Visigoths, Huns, Burgundians, Vandals, Franks, Lombards), their culture and impact on empire, Justinians reconquests.
cmCourseInfo.title: Barbarian Invasions and the Fall of the Roman Empire

courses.name: Rites of Passage and Daily Life in the Middle Ages

cmCourseInfo.description: Reflecting on the life cycle and rites of passage in the medieval period gives the opportunity to study the daily lives of peasants, nobles, monks, nuns, and burghers, and to observe from an interesting angle the differences between female and male life experiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rites of Passage and Daily Life in the Middle Ages
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A course specifically on the Middle Ages such as HIS220Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates the development of Rome from its mythical foundations, through the Empire, the Middle Ages, Renaissance and Baroque to the modern city, illustrating the shift from the pagan to the papal city and its emergence as the capital of a united Italy after 1870 and a modern European metropolis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rome: The City in History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least 1.0 credit European History course(s)
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: VIC348Y1 (offered in Fall/Winter 2012-2013, 2013-2014, 2014-2015 and 2015-2016) and VIC162H1 (offered in Fall 2016, Fall 2017 and Fall 2018)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures delivered synchronously, live-streamed and recorded with some in-person opportunities should public health measures permit.

cmCourseInfo.description: The history of the Baltic countries, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania from 1900 to the present day, with emphasis on the emergence of independent Baltic states, World War II, communist era, the Baltic Revolution, the restoration of independence and European integration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Baltic History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: German state policy towards the Jews in the context of racist ideology, bureaucratic structures, and varying conditions in German-occupied Europe. Second Term considers responses of Jews, European populations and governments, the Allies, churches, and political movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Holocaust, to 1942 (formerly HIS338Y1/398Y1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Completion of six undergraduate full-course equivalents
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: A course in modern European history

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Hy-Flex:  Lectures delivered synchronously, live-streamed and recorded permitting synchronous and asynchronous attendance with some in-person opportunities should public health measures permit.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the history of the Ottoman Empire from the beginning of the 19th c. until its dissolution in the course of World War I. Topics include Ottoman reforms, relations between the Empire’s populations and the state, the diplomatic interactions known as “the Eastern Question,” the Young Turk revolution, gender, and intellectual, cultural and artistic developments.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Ottoman Empire, 1800-1922
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 FCE 200-level HIS course(s)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lecture will be delivered online synchronously.  In addition to a computer, tablet, etc., students will need a microphone, sot that they can ask questions or make comments on the material.

courses.name: Conflict and Co-operation in the International System Since 1945

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the conduct and consequences of international politics in an atomic/nuclear age when the stakes of the Great Game were not just the fates of states and nations, but the survival of humanity itself. The diplomatic, strategic and economic aspects of international relations will all receive appropriate elucidation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Conflict and Co-operation in the International System Since 1945

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Rice, Sugar, and Spice in Southeast Asia:  a History of Food in the Region

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the importance of food products in the livelihoods of the inhabitants of Southeast and in the world economy. It traces the circulation of these products within the Southeast Asian region in the pre-modern period, into the spice trade of the early modern era, and the establishment of coffee and sugar plantations in the late colonial period, and the role of these exports in the contemporary global economy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rice, Sugar, and Spice in Southeast Asia:  a History of Food in the Region

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered asynchronously with opportunities for students to participate in optional weekly synchronous discussion sessions led by the instructor.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines class, distinction and community through the lens of the English country house from 1837 to 1939. Topics include owners, servants, houses, collections, gardens and rituals such as fox hunting.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Country House in England 1837-1939
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A course in British or European history

courses.name: History of Britain: Struggle for Power

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the history of modern England with emphasis on the search for identity with reference to the nation, the crown, class, gender, age, political parties, race and ethnicity.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of Britain: Struggle for Power

courses.name: A History of Women in Pre-colonial East Africa

cmCourseInfo.description:
This course examines the lived experience of women in societies, communities and polities of varying sizes across territories that cover eight contemporary East African states. It encompasses the period from 1000 B.C to the end of the nineteenth century. Topics covered are clustered under four broad themes: a) Ecology, work in commodity production, wealth and exchange relations; b) “Institutional” power, ideology and structures; c) “Creative” power particularly in the areas of healing, resistance/contestation and transformation; and d) Violence, war and vulnerability.

The course challenges present day gender and identity categories applied to Africa’s deep past and highlights critical nuances of gender, identity and power dynamics in Africa.
cmCourseInfo.title: A History of Women in Pre-colonial East Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NEW150Y1 or any course in African History

cmCourseInfo.description: Social and political history of Poland from the 10th to the 20th century. Analysis of the political history in a broader, central European context; consequences of Christianization of medieval Poland and the Polish-Lithuanian union; Sarmatian culture, Antemurale, Polish Messianism and Cordon sanitaire.
cmCourseInfo.title: Poland: A Crossroads of Europe
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS251Y1/permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered synchronously, live-streamed and recorded permitting asynchronous attendance with some in-person opportunities should public health measures permit.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course surveys major themes and developments in the history of medicine from c.600 BCE to 1800 CE. Topics include: Hippocrates, Galen and their reception in the Middle Ages; monasteries, medicinal gardens and hospitals; medieval licensing of physicians and pharmacists; medieval scholastic medicine; the Black Death; Renaissance anatomy and charlatans; New World drug discoveries; William Harvey's heart, William Witherings's foxglove, the isolation of morphine.
cmCourseInfo.title: A History of Pre-modern Medicine
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 1.0 FCE in medieval or pre-modern history, or permission of course instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Online synchronous lectures with opportunity for in-person attendance should public health measures permit

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method and time changed.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method and time changed.

cmCourseInfo.description: Follows on HIS338H1. Themes include: resistance by Jews and non-Jews; local collaboration; the roles of European governments, the Allies, the churches, and other international organizations; the varieties of Jewish responses. We will also focus on postwar repercussions of the Holocaust in areas such as justice, memory and memorialization, popular culture and politics.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Holocaust, from 1942
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: completion of 6 undergraduate full-course equivalents and HIS338H1
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: a course in modern European history

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

courses.name: Dynamics of Gender in Canadian History

cmCourseInfo.description: A lecture course which deals thematically with gender issues in Canadian history (including familial roles, changing patterns of work and employment, and participation in the public sphere).
cmCourseInfo.title: Dynamics of Gender in Canadian History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS263Y1/HIS264H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures Asynchronous (1 hour/week). In September, students to sign up for 1 hour weekly discussion, synchronous and online.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

courses.name: From Revolution to Revolution: Hungary Since 1848

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a chronological survey of the history of Hungary from the 1848 revolution until the present. It is ideal for students with little or no knowledge of Hungarian history but who posess an understanding of the main trends of European history in the 19th and 20th centuries. The focus is on the revolutions of 1848-1849, 1918-1919, the 1956 Revolution against Soviet rule and the collapse of communism in 1989. The story has not been invariably heroic, violent and tragic.
cmCourseInfo.title: From Revolution to Revolution: Hungary Since 1848
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A 100 level HIS course

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the history of Canadian politics from the late colonial period to the recent past. Lectures and tutorials will focus attention on specific political issues (responsible government, Confederation, war, welfare, battles over voting rights, campaigns for social change, etc) but also consider the deeper structural, social, economic, and cultural dynamics that shaped politics over time. The course takes a broad view of politics (elections and parties but also social movements, interest groups, bureaucracy). A key theme is the nature of political power in a democratic polity.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Political History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS264H1/HIS263Y1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will explore the history of all types of servants, from the ladies-in-waiting to the domestic slaves, in Western Europe between 1000 and 1700. The goal will be to observe especially their working and living conditions, as well as the changing perception of service through time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Servants and Masters, 1000- 1700
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A course on the Middle Ages or on the early Modern Period

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will explore the history of all types of servants, from the ladies-in-waiting to the domestic slaves, in Western Europe between 1000 and 1700. The goal will be to observe especially their working and living conditions, as well as the changing perception of service through time.
cmCourseInfo.title: Servants and Masters, 1000- 1700
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A course on the Middle Ages or on the early Modern Period

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of American foreign relations from 1898 to the present. Themes include imperial expansion and the uses of power; the relationship of business and government in U.S. foreign policy; and the role of culture and ideas in Americas relations with the world.
cmCourseInfo.title: 20th-Century American Foreign Relations

courses.name: China from the Mongols to the Last Emperor

cmCourseInfo.description: This course traces the history of Chinese empire from its political reorganization, economic expansion, and cultural efflorescence in the 11th century, through its peak of power in the 18th century, and to its decline during the 19th. We will consider how these centuries broke with as well as continued previous developments, and how they have influenced Chinese and world history in the last 150 years.
cmCourseInfo.title: China from the Mongols to the Last Emperor
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS280Y1/EAS103H1/EAS209H1 or comparable course in E. Asian/Chinese history

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course subjects our increasing knowledge about African women’s history from the mid-19th century to the present to critical analysis. It goes beyond restoring women to history and seeing African women as victims impacted upon and struggling against colonialism and neo-colonialism. It examines how African women’s lived experiences have been represented, packaged, and delivered to different audiences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women in African History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS295Y1/HIS297Y1/NEW150Y1/NEW250Y1/NEW351Y1/POL301Y1 or permission from the Instructor

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of political, economic, and social change in the British colony of Hong Kong from 1842 until the present day.
cmCourseInfo.title: The History of Hong Kong
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Students cannot take both the Y and H version of HIS385

cmCourseInfo.description: A comparative and transnational examination of fascist movements and regimes in Europe during 1919-1945. Beginning with Mussolini in Italy and Hitler in Germany, this course analyzes manifestations of the phenomenon in various European countries, including France, Spain, the Baltic states, Central Europe and Scandinavia. We analyze the factors that led to fascist movements obtaining power in certain countries and to their failure in others. Collaboration with Nazi Germany during the Second World War is also explored. Finally, we discuss whether the concept of ‘generic’ fascism can also be applied to other regions and periods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fascism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 9.0 FCE including 1.0 FCE in HIS courses
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS389H1 (Topics in History: Fascism), offered in Winter 2018 and Winter 2019

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures live-streamed and recorded permitting both synchronous and asynchronous attendance with in-person opportunity should public health guidelines permit.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of French society, politics and culture from the Paris Commune to the 1990s. Special attention is paid to watersheds like the Dreyfus Affair and the Vichy regime, to issues of regionalism/nationalism, cultural pluralism, women's rights, intellectual and cultural trends, and decolonization.
cmCourseInfo.title: France Since 1830
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EUR200Y1/one course in HIS/FRE

Delivery Instructions

LEC0301/9301: Lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously, learning is self-paced and not reliant on a meeting schedule. Interactive sessions are delivered online on Thursday, 3-4 pm. Students will need to use several functions within Quercus (Discussion Boards, BB Collaborate) and the ability to use MSTeams or Zoom for interactive sessions.

Delivery Instructions

LEC5101/6101: Recorded lectures will be posted on-line and accessible asynchronously.  There will be a 1-hour tutorial component synchronous and online on Tuesdays, 17:00-18:00. Any student unable to attend this session should contact Professor Cohen.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores implications for history and its methods of the shift from print to digital sources. Imparts introductory skills in the manipulation digital media, such as the use of maps, GIS and big data.
cmCourseInfo.title: Digital History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 200-level History course or one of WDW235H1/WDW236H1

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an opportunity for exceptional third-year students to undertake an independent research project on a topic for which there is not a suitable course offering. Students must be enrolled in either a History Specialist or Major program; have taken at least 3.0 FCE in HIS with a B+ average; and have approval of an instructor willing to supervise the project. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

courses.name: The Progressive Era and Rise of Big Business in America

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the rise of big business in America and its relationship to social and economic changes in United States in the so-called Progressive Era (roughly 1880-1920). We will focus on several themes: the evolution and characteristics of big business; rise of organized labor; evolution of business-government relations; social and economic reform movements; and the changing status of immigrants, African Americans, and women (both white and African-American). In short, we will be studying a pivotal moment in the transformation of modern American society.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Progressive Era and Rise of Big Business in America
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS389H1 (Topics in History: Business and Society), offered in Fall 2016 and HIS372H1 (Topics in U.S. History: The Progressive Era and Rise of Big Business), offered in Winter 2018

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures live-streamed and recorded permitting both synchronous and asynchronous attendance. There will be opportunities for both synchronous and asynchronous discussion through zoom sessions and an online discussion board

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers international relations from World War II to the collapse of the Soviet Union. Topics include the breakdown of the wartime alliance, Soviet predominance in eastern Europe, the Western response, NATO, atomic weaponry.
cmCourseInfo.title: History of the Cold War
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS311Y1/HIS344H1/HIS344Y1/HIS377H1

courses.name: Canada By Treaty: Alliances, Title Transfers and Land Claims

cmCourseInfo.description: A detailed study of the treaty process between indigenous peoples and newcomers in Canadian history, with examination of the shift between alliance treaties to land surrender agreements from the colonial period through to the signing of recent treaties including the Nunavut Land Claims Agreement and the Nisga’a Final Agreement.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canada By Treaty: Alliances, Title Transfers and Land Claims
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS263Y1/HIS264H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

cmCourseInfo.description: Deals with issues of orality, literacy, gender, class, cultural bricolage and vernacular epistemology – the constituents of popular, as opposed to elite knowledge - through the study of folklore, magic, religion, drink, sex, riot and festivity in early modern England. Some background in medieval and/or early modern history or literature is highly recommended. Extensive work will be undertaken with primary printed sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Modern English Popular Culture, 1500-1800
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: One of HIS101Y1/HIS109Y1/HIS220Y1/HIS243H1/HIS244H1/HIS368H1/HIS337H1/HIS349H1/HIS357Y1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: HIS496H1 (Topics in History: Early Modern English Popular Culture, 1600-1800), offered in Summer 2018

courses.name: Social History of Medicine in the 19th& 20th Centuries

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to current issues in the social history of medicine and some of the major developments in the modern history of the discipline. The format is class discussion based on themes covered in the course textbook, covering such topics as the history of the doctor-patient relationship, changes in physicians' social status, changing attitudes toward the body, and the evolution of various medical and surgical specialites including obstetrics and gynecology. (Joint undergraduate-graduate).
cmCourseInfo.title: Social History of Medicine in the 19th& 20th Centuries

notes.name: Course Note

cmCourseInfo.description: The first goal of this seminar is to help students read the sources with a more critical eye, especially narrative sources (Lives of Saints) and normative sources (rules and customaries). The second goal is to study the evolution of the monastic ideal from its origin to the 12th century. (Joint undergraduate-graduate)
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval Institutes of Perfection
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A course specifically on the Middle Ages such as HIS220Y1

courses.name: Gender and Slavery in the Atlantic World

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the relationship between gender and the experience of slavery and emancipating several Atlantic world societies from the 17th-19th centuries. Areas to be covered are the Caribbean, Brazil, the U.S. South, West and South Africa and Western Europe.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Slavery in the Atlantic World
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS291H1/HIS294Y1/(HIS230H1, HIS231H1)/HIS295Y1

courses.name: World War II in East Central Europe

cmCourseInfo.description: The fall of the Versailles system, German and Soviet diplomatic and military activities and their occupational policies in East Central Europe during World War II, economic exploitation, collaboration, resistance, and genocide in the discussed region, its liberation and sovietization in 1944-1945. (Joint undergraduate-graduate)
cmCourseInfo.title: World War II in East Central Europe
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: EUR200Y1/HIS251Y1/HIS334H1

courses.name: French Colonial Indochina: History, Cultures, Texts, Film

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines French colonial Indochina through several different lenses. Themes include the cross-cultural contact zones between colonial and colonized societies, imperial culture, expressions of colonial power, and forms of opposition. Colonial novels, translated resistance literature, documentaries, and films are utilized as primary sources to be examined critically.
cmCourseInfo.title: French Colonial Indochina: History, Cultures, Texts, Film
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT344Y1/EAS204Y1/GGR342H1/HIS104Y1/HIS107Y1/HIS280Y1/HIS283Y1/HIS284Y1/HIS315H1/HIS388H1/NEW369Y1

notes.name: Course Note

Students will need to be able to access Zoom

courses.name: History, Rights, and Difference in South Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: Addressing South Asian history after 1750, this course examines ideas of rights, contract, and the rule of law in colonial and postcolonial contexts. Attention is paid to the intellectual history of rights and the central place of colonial and postcolonial questions within that history. Topics include rights and questions concerning indigenous culture, caste and customary practice, gender and capitalist development.
cmCourseInfo.title: History, Rights, and Difference in South Asia
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A mark of 73% or higher in HIS282Y1 or instructors permission
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Background in political and social theory and some background in South Asia

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

It is highly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera to participate in online seminar discussion and activities

courses.name: Emancipate Yourselves from Mental Slavery? Historical Narratives of Caribbean Decolonisation

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is a critical intellectual history of Caribbean decolonisation. It begins with the Haitian Revolution, exploring and comparing how history was mobilized to structure anti-colonial theories about the making of postcolonial Caribbean societies. Key conceptual frameworks to be examined include indegenism, noirism, creolization, metissage; Caribbean interpretations of Marxism, Negritude and Pan-Aricanism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Emancipate Yourselves from Mental Slavery? Historical Narratives of Caribbean Decolonisation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS294Y1/(HIS230H1, HIS231H1)

Compulsory for all Specialists undertaking a one-semester dissertation. Weekly seminars provide training in reviewing literature, writing research proposals, formulating hypotheses and oral presentation of findings.

History Specialists only. Students must find topics and thesis supervisors. Not eligible for CR/NCR option. See department website for pre-requisites and specific registration instructions. (http://history.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/senior-thesis)

courses.name: Topics in the Social and Cultural History of Victorian Britain

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of the impact of industrialism on Victorian society and values. Concentration on Victorian social critics including Engels, Owen, Maynew, Dickens and Morris.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in the Social and Cultural History of Victorian Britain
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: A course in modern British History/Victorian literature

courses.name: The Car in North American History

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar examines the history of the car in North America from the perspective of technology, business, landscape and popular culture. Particular attention is paid to issues of production, consumption, geography, and daily life, and to the importance of class race, gender, region, and age in shaping the meaning and experience of car culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Car in North American History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: HIS263Y1/HIS264H1/HIS271Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Lectures Asynchronous online, seminars synchronous and online.

Students will need to be able to access Quercus and BB collaborate

courses.name: The History of Psychiatry and Psychiatric Illness

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to current issues in the history of psychiatry and some of the major developments in the evolution of this unique medical specialty. the format is class discussion based on themes covered in the course textbook, covering such topics as changing perspectives on the nature of psychotic illness, the psychoneuroses, disorders of the mind/body relationship, psychiatric diagnosis, and presentations of illness. (Joint undergraduate-graduate).
cmCourseInfo.title: The History of Psychiatry and Psychiatric Illness

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar explores issues of everyday life in Soviet Russia during the Stalin era. What was the Soviet normal? Topics will include belief systems, dreams and myths, terror, fear, repression, and resistance. Texts include a range of different sources, memoirs, diaries, official state documents, and secondary sources.
cmCourseInfo.title: Everyday Stalinism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: grade of A in HIS250Y1/grade of B+ or higher in HIS351Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Seminar will be online synchronous, Tues. 3-5

No recordings will be made. 

Students will have no video to review prior to class meetings (except for assignments). 

The class is a seminar that depends on participation, so students’ computers must have a mic and camera. 

These can be internal to the computer. 

We will use Zoom.
